start.title:
NeuroBoost

Statistical Truth Behind Marketing
start.description: Can statistical analysis save Blake from a $300K mistake? Join investment manager Blake Thompson and neuroscientist Dr. Elena Rivera as they investigate whether NeuroBoost's focus and memory improvement claims hold up under scientific scrutiny. You'll learn to distinguish flawed studies from rigorous experiments and apply statistical methods to separate genuine effects from marketing hype.

S2_D1_FX_C0.heading: Welcome to Evidence-Based Decision Making
S2_D1_FX_C0.body: Blake Thompson needs your help evaluating a major investment in NeuroBoost, a supplement that claims to improve focus and memory by 40%. Today, you will learn how to use proper experimental design, randomization, and statistical analysis to uncover the truth. You will discover how data analysis separates science from marketing claims—and helps make smart business decisions worth hundreds of thousands of dollars.

S3.S3_D1_FX_C2: Elena! I haven't seen you since high school! You're definitely the most famous neuroscientist I know!
S3.S3_D2_FX_C1: Thank you, Blake. Now, you said you needed my advice?
S3.S3_D3_FX_C2: Yes! I'd really like your honest opinion about a new investment opportunity. I'm looking at a company called NeuroBoost—they make supplements that claim to measurably improve brain function.
S3.S3_D4_FX_C1: Interesting. What exactly are they claiming?
S3.S3_D5_FX_C2: They just posted a study on their website where participants reported a 40% cognitive function improvement in just four weeks!
S3.S3_D6_FX_C1: 40% improvement in cognition? I mean, that would be a billion-dollar pill—if it worked.
S3.S3_D7_FX_C2: I know, right? That's why I'm thinking of investing big. Three hundred thousand from our fund.
S3.S3_D8_FX_C1: I have to admit I'm skeptical. But I'm curious to know more. Can you tell me about the study?

S4.S4_D1_FX_C2: Sure! So first, they created an online memory assessment test. Anyone could take it, and about 500 people completed it.
S4.S4_D2_FX_C1: And what did the data look like?
S4.S4_D3_FX_C2: They showed me this graph of all memory scores—it looked like a bell curve, you know? Most people scored somewhere in the middle, with fewer people at the really high or really low ends.
S4.S4_D4_FX_C1: That's what we call a normal distribution. Very common for traits like memory performance. What happened next?
S4.S4_D5_FX_C2:
Then they asked if anyone wanted to volunteer to take part in the study. About 100 people from that group of 500 signed up.
After four weeks of taking NeuroBoost, their memory scores improved by an average of 40%. Pretty impressive, right?
S4.S4_D6_FX_C1: Hmm. Blake, before we get excited about that 40% number, let me ask you something. Did they tell you which ones decided to sign up?
S4.S4_D7_FX_C2: Uh... I don't think they mentioned that specifically. Does it matter?
S4.S4_D8_FX_C1: Oh, it matters a lot. In fact, this might be the key to understanding why their results are so inflated. Let me show you something.

S5_D0_FX_C9.title: Volunteer Selection Simulator
S5_D0_FX_C9.volunteersNotRepresentative: Volunteers are not representative of the general population.

about.heading: About Volunteer Selection and Self-Selection Bias
about.body:
• This interactive tool shows how volunteer selection can distort data in scientific studies. The blue bars show a normal distribution of memory performance in the general population.
  • Most people's memory scores are near the mean, forming a bell-shaped distribution pattern where taller bars represent more people in that score range.
  • When volunteers are selected, those with lower memory performance (lower score ranges on the left side of the chart) are more likely to participate. This creates self-selection bias, meaning the sample no longer represents the entire population.

help.heading: How to Use this Tool?
help.body:
• This tool shows how volunteers in a study may differ from the general population.
  • Observe the blue bars — they represent the entire population's memory performance across different score ranges.
  • Click "Simulate Volunteer Selection" to see which individuals choose to volunteer for a memory supplement study.
  • Compare the red bars (volunteers) to the blue bars (general population) to see how the sample changes.
  • Think about what happens to the average performance of volunteers compared to the general population and why that might occur.

S5.S5_D1_FX_C1: Here's what a normal distribution of memory scores looks like for 500 people. Most people cluster in the middle, with fewer at the extremes.
S5.S5_D2_FX_C2: Right, that's the bell curve pattern they showed me.
S5.S5_D3_FX_C1:
Now, here's the critical question:
When NeuroBoost puts out a call asking 'Do you want to take part in this study?'—who do you think responded?
Click 'Simulate Volunteer Selection' to find out.
S5.S5_D4_FX_C2: Whoa! They're almost all on the left side—the people with lower memory scores!
S5.S5_D5_FX_C1: Exactly! This is called self-selection bias. People who are worried about their memory are much more likely to volunteer. People already doing well don't feel the need.
S5.S5_D6_FX_C2: So the 100 volunteers weren't representative—they were mostly the ones with worse memory to begin with?
S5.S5_D7_FX_C1: Precisely. When people start from below-average scores and then they improve, part of that improvement comes from practice effects and the placebo effect: believing something works often creates real improvement.
S5.S5_D8_FX_C2: So the 40% improvement might not be from the supplement at all?
S5.S5_D9_FX_C1: It could be a combination of all these factors. With this study design, we have no way to separate them. The volunteer selection bias makes the result unreliable.
S5.S5_D10_FX_C2: I see the problem now. We can't trust the 40% claim... How would you test this correctly?

S6.S6_D1_FX_C1: We should contact NeuroBoost and suggest they conduct a proper randomized controlled trial—an RCT. That's the only way to get reliable results.
S6.S6_D2_FX_C2: Do you think they'd agree to that?
S6.S6_D3_FX_C1: I think they would agree to do it. A properly conducted trial would give them real credibility. Let me explain what that would look like.

S7_D0_FX_C9.title: Study Design
S7_D0_FX_C9.doubleBlindDescription: Neither participants nor researchers know who got what.

about.heading: About Proper Study Design
about.body:
• This interactive shows how a randomized controlled trial (RCT) is structured to test whether a treatment really works.
  • Researchers start by recruiting a group of participants — for example, 100 people. To ensure fairness, each participant is randomly assigned to one of two groups:

    Random Assignment: P(Treatment) = P(Control) = 12

  • Treatment Group: Receives the actual treatment (e.g., NeuroBoost).
  • Control Group: Receives a placebo, a pill that looks identical but has no active ingredient.
  • Afterward, both groups' outcomes are measured.
  • This setup removes bias and placebo effects, making sure that any differences in outcomes are due to the treatment itself — not expectations or chance.

help.heading: How to Use this Tool?
help.body:
• This interactive shows the structure of a proper randomized controlled trial (RCT).
  • Watch as the flowchart builds step by step, showing how participants are recruited, randomly assigned to groups, receive treatments, and have their outcomes measured.
  • Notice how the process ensures both groups are comparable and how the study design eliminates bias.
  • Use this tool to understand the key components of a well-designed scientific study.

S7.S7_D1_FX_C1: A proper randomized controlled trial has several key components. Let me walk you through the structure.
S7.S7_D2_FX_C1: First, we recruit participants properly—not through self-selection, but through random sampling to get a more representative sample. For this study, we selected 100 participants randomly.
S7.S7_D3_FX_C2: Okay, 100 people. Then what?
S7.S7_D4_FX_C1: Then comes the most important part—random assignment. We randomly divide the 100 participants into two groups of 50 each. Each person has an equal chance of being in either group.
S7.S7_D5_FX_C2: And what does each group get?
S7.S7_D6_FX_C1:
Treatment Group: 50 people receive the actual NeuroBoost supplement.
Control Group: 50 people receive a placebo—a pill that looks identical but contains no active ingredients.
S7.S7_D7_FX_C2: So half get the real thing, half get a fake pill?
S7.S7_D8_FX_C1: Exactly. And here's the crucial part—this is a blind study. The participants don't know who got the real supplement.
S7.S7_D9_FX_C2: Why go through all that trouble?
S7.S7_D10_FX_C1: To eliminate bias. If participants knew they got the placebo, it might affect their performance.
S7.S7_D11_FX_C2: So both groups get measured at the end, and if the treatment group improves more than the control group, we know it's because of NeuroBoost?
S7.S7_D12_FX_C1: Precisely! Because both groups had the same expectations, the same practice effects. The only difference is one group got NeuroBoost and the other didn't.
S7.S7_D13_FX_C2: That makes sense. But you mentioned randomization was important—why exactly?
S7.S7_D14_FX_C1: Great question. Let me show you what randomization actually does.

S8_D0_FX_C9.title: Randomization Simulator
S8_D0_FX_C9.randomizationProducesBalancedGroups: Randomization produces balanced groups with similar baseline memory scores, ensuring any difference in outcomes is due to NeuroBoost, not pre-existing differences.

about.heading: About Randomization in Experiments
about.body:
• Randomization is a key step in designing a fair and unbiased experiment. It ensures that all participant characteristics—both known and unknown — are distributed equally between the treatment and control groups.
  • This interactive tool visualizes the randomization process. Each colored dot represents a participant with a baseline memory score. The shade of blue indicates their score: lighter shades represent lower scores, darker shades represent higher scores.
  • When you click "Randomize," the 100 participants are randomly divided into two groups of 50 each. Watch as the participants drop into their assigned groups, and notice how the mix of colors (scores) is balanced between the two groups.
  • After randomization, you can view the analysis showing histograms and statistics for each group. This demonstrates how randomization creates balanced groups with similar baseline characteristics, ensuring that any differences in outcomes can be attributed to the treatment itself.

help.heading: How to Use this Tool?
help.body:
• Observe the initial pool of 100 participants. Each colored dot represents a participant with a different baseline memory score.
  • Click the "Randomize" button to randomly assign participants to the NeuroBoost and Placebo groups.
  • Watch the animation as participants drop into their assigned groups. Notice how the mix of colors (representing different scores) becomes balanced between groups.
  • After randomization completes, click "See Analysis" to view detailed histograms and statistics showing how balanced the groups are.
  • Use the "Reset" button to start over and randomize again, or click "Back to Randomization" to return to the visualization view.

S8.S8_D1_FX_C1: Look at this visualization. We have all 100 participants from our study, color-coded by their baseline memory score.
S8.S8_D2_FX_C1: The lighter colors represent lower memory scores, and darker colors represent higher scores. This gradient shows the natural variation in memory ability across our participants.
S8.S8_D3_FX_C2: I can see the full range—from light to dark.
S8.S8_D4_FX_C1: Now, we need to split them into treatment and control groups. Watch what happens when we randomize. Click the 'Randomize' button.
S8.S8_D5_FX_C2: Oh wow, they're dividing up... and it looks like both groups have a similar mix of light and dark shades.
S8.S8_D6_FX_C1: That's the beauty of randomization! By assigning people randomly, we naturally create groups that are balanced. Now click 'See Analysis' to look at the actual numbers.
S8.S8_D7_FX_C2: The average baseline memory scores are very close.
S8.S8_D8_FX_C1: Exactly! For all practical purposes, these two groups are starting from the same place. Both groups have similar baseline memory scores, similar everything.
S8.S8_D9_FX_C2: So randomization makes sure we're comparing apples to apples?
S8.S8_D10_FX_C1:
Perfect analogy. And here's why it matters:
When we measure outcomes after four weeks, we KNOW both groups started from the same baseline. So if one group improves more than the other, we can confidently say that the difference is due to the treatment—not to pre-existing differences.
S8.S8_D11_FX_C2: Because any small differences at the start are just random chances?
S8.S8_D12_FX_C1: Exactly! You're getting it. This is the foundation of causal inference in science. Randomization lets us say the treatment CAUSED the difference in outcomes.
S8.S8_D13_FX_C2: Okay, I'm convinced this is the right way to test it. Will you help me convince NeuroBoost to do this study?
S8.S8_D14_FX_C1: Absolutely. I'll reach out to them and propose the study design. A properly conducted trial like this will take about 6 to 8 weeks to complete.
S8.S8_D15_FX_C2: That's worth the wait if it means getting credible answers.

S9.S9_D1_FX_C1: Here we go. We got actual trial data from 100 participants—50 in each group—with their pre-test scores, post-test scores, and improvement percentages.
S9.S9_D2_FX_C2: This is it. The moment of truth.
S9.S9_D3_FX_C1: Let's start by comparing the two groups directly. I'll show you the improvement percentages side by side.

S10_D0_FX_C9.title: Group Comparison
S10_D0_FX_C9.subtitle: Randomized Controlled Trial (n=80)
S10_D0_FX_C9.keyFinding: Key Finding: The supplement shows a ~5% effect above placebo—far less than the 40% claim.

about.heading: About Box Plots
about.body:
• Box plots (also called box-and-whisker plots) are a standardized way to display the distribution of data based on five key statistics: minimum, first quartile (Q1), median, third quartile (Q3), and maximum.
  • The box represents the middle 50% of the data (interquartile range or IQR), showing where most values fall. The thick horizontal line inside the box marks the median — the middle value when data is sorted.
  • The whiskers (vertical lines extending from the box) show the range of typical values, extending to 1.5 times the IQR. Points beyond the whiskers are outliers — unusual values that fall outside the normal range.
  • The white circle indicates the mean (average) value. In this visualization, comparing the two box plots reveals that the placebo group improved by ~4% while the NeuroBoost group improved by ~9%, showing a true treatment effect of only ~5% — far less than the advertised 40% claim.
  • Box plots are powerful tools for comparing groups because they show not just averages, but the entire distribution — revealing spread, symmetry, and outliers at a glance.

S10.S10_D1_FX_C2: The placebo group improved by about 4%... and NeuroBoost by about 9%.
S10.S10_D2_FX_C2: Wait—that's only a 5% difference! Not 40%!
S10.S10_D3_FX_C1: Exactly. The placebo group shows the power of expectation alone—4% improvement without any active ingredient. NeuroBoost adds 5% on top of that.
S10.S10_D4_FX_C2: So the actual effect of the supplement is just 5%? That's way less than they claimed!
S10.S10_D5_FX_C1: What does the 4% placebo improvement tell us?

question_1.option_2: People improve from practice effects and expectations alone

S10.S10_D6_FX_C2: Right—people get better just from believing they're taking something effective.
S10.S10_D7_FX_C1: Exactly. But here's the critical question: is this 5% difference real, or could it be a random chance? Let's check the statistical significance.

S11_D0_FX_C9.title: Statistical Significance
S11_D0_FX_C9.confidentTrueEffect: 95% confident true effect is between {ciLower}% and {ciUpper}%

S11.S11_D1_FX_C2: What does p-value = 0.003 mean?
S11.S11_D2_FX_C1: It means there's less than a 0.3% probability that this result happened by chance. We often use 0.05 or 5% as a cutoff. If the p-value is less than 0.05, the result is likely related to the intervention instead of due to chance alone. In this case, since p is below 0.05, the difference is statistically significant—the supplement genuinely works.
S11.S11_D3_FX_C2: And that confidence interval?
S11.S11_D4_FX_C1: We're 95% confident the supplement's effect is improvement between 3.2% and 6.8%. Even in the worst case, it's still meaningful improvement.
S11.S11_D5_FX_C1: What does p < 0.05 tell us?

question_1.option_2: The difference is unlikely due to random chance

S11.S11_D6_FX_C2: So NeuroBoost works, just not as dramatically as claimed. But 5% is still real?
S11.S11_D7_FX_C1: Absolutely. A 5% cognitive boost is clinically meaningful.

S12.S12_D1_FX_C1: So what's your decision?
S12.S12_D2_FX_C2: I'm still investing. But I'll insist on honest marketing. 'Clinically proven 5% cognitive improvement' builds trust. Overpromising just leads to disappointed customers.
S12.S12_D3_FX_C1: That's exactly the right approach. What's the most important thing you learned today?
S12.S12_D4_FX_C2: That self-selection bias can completely skew results. Without proper recruitment and random assignment, you can't separate real effects from bias, practice effects, and placebo.
S12.S12_D5_FX_C1: And the 4% placebo improvement wasn't wasted—it showed us how powerful expectations are. The supplement adds real benefits on top of that.
S12.S12_D6_FX_C2: I also learned that randomization is the key. It creates balanced groups so we can fairly compare outcomes and actually prove causation.
S12.S12_D7_FX_C1: Exactly. Statistics isn't about limiting claims—it's about finding truth. And truth, it turns out, is good enough to build a business on.
S12.S12_D8_FX_C2: Better than good enough. It's profitable and ethical. That's the kind of business I want to build.

quest_completion.subheading: You've Uncovered the Truth Behind the Hype!
quest_completion.content:
You successfully completed the NeuroBoost Statistical Investigation STEAMQuest.

Key Achievements:

  • You identified fatal flaws in uncontrolled observational studies and learned why proper experimental design matters
  • You discovered how randomization creates fair comparisons by distributing confounding variables equally between groups
  • You analyzed real clinical trial data using boxplots, p-values, and confidence intervals to reveal the true 5% effect
  • You explored normal distributions to make precise population predictions about treatment effectiveness

Keep applying statistical thinking to separate genuine effects from marketing hype in our data-driven world!

common.char1_description: A mature woman with gray hair, glasses, a lab coat, blue shirt, and black pants, holding a tablet.
common.char2_description: A man with curly hair, glasses, white shirt, dark gray coat, black tie and black pants, holding a tablet.
common.bg1_description: A futuristic building with curved architecture, trees, a clear sky, and people outside.
common.bg2_description: An open office with workstations, people collaborating, and screens showing scientific data.
common.bg3_description: A workspace with a desk, monitors showing data, and a city view through windows.
common.bg4_description: A lab space with glass walls, shelves of books, and scientists discussing near a screen.
common.bg5_description: A modern office with windows, people at desks, and a display showing graphs and data.
